s.text: Many genes were modulated similarly in all of the cell lines, suggesting conservation of a specific androgen-responsive program, perhaps a vestige of the prostatic epithelial phenotype, between these cell lines (Figure 3; see also [ 12] and Additional data files).
Full gene names and GenBank accession numbers for Figure 3
Androgen treatment also induced a number of genes that participate in protein folding and glycosylation (Figure 5b).

Many previous studies have pointed to a critical role for the cytoskeleton and extracellular matrix in transducing signals for growth, differentiation and secretion in normal and cancerous prostate cells [ 32].
After puberty, the normal prostate produces a protein- and organic solute-rich fluid that contributes approximately 30-50% of the volume of the ejaculate.
These data may also offer some insight into the contribution of the prostate to the normal seminal fluid, including molecular components that may be important in fertility.
It is possible that some of these pathways have important roles in reprogramming the normal prostate cell in response to androgen [ 33].
These data may also offer some insight into the contribution of the prostate to the normal seminal fluid, including molecular components that may be important in fertility.
These data may also offer some insight into the contribution of the prostate to the normal seminal fluid, including molecular components that may be important in fertility.
We recognize that the in vitro model systems used here offer at best only an approximation of normal and cancerous prostatic epithelia.

Cholesterol and lipids are also found at high levels in semen and are major components of secretory vesicles referred to as prostasomes, which are thought to regulate the function of spermatozoa [ 27].
Expression levels changed more than twofold in 539 (95%) of the transcripts.

Cholesterol and lipids are also found at high levels in semen and are major components of secretory vesicles referred to as prostasomes, which are thought to regulate the function of spermatozoa [ 27].
Our data may therefore help point to one important feature of the transcriptional program that sets the stage for these signaling events.
The similarity of the transcriptional responses among the four androgen-responsive cell lines suggests that this expression program may be intrinsic to prostatic epithelial cell function.

For the experiments described in our study, the raw expression ratio dataset was filtered, using the program Cluster [ 43], for genes whose transcript levels differ from their median value by at least 1.5-fold in androgen-treated cells compared to controls in at least two experiments (with not more than 30% of measurements discarded because of poor data quality for each entry).

For the experiments described in our study, the raw expression ratio dataset was filtered, using the program Cluster [ 43], for genes whose transcript levels differ from their median value by at least 1.5-fold in androgen-treated cells compared to controls in at least two experiments (with not more than 30% of measurements discarded because of poor data quality for each entry).

For the experiments described in our study, the raw expression ratio dataset was filtered, using the program Cluster [ 43], for genes whose transcript levels differ from their median value by at least 1.5-fold in androgen-treated cells compared to controls in at least two experiments (with not more than 30% of measurements discarded because of poor data quality for each entry).

For the experiments described in our study, the raw expression ratio dataset was filtered, using the program Cluster [ 43], for genes whose transcript levels differ from their median value by at least 1.5-fold in androgen-treated cells compared to controls in at least two experiments (with not more than 30% of measurements discarded because of poor data quality for each entry).

For example, the transcript levels of 310 of these genes changed by 1.5-fold or more in MDA PCa 2a and 2b cells following 48 hours of exposure to R1881; transcripts for 262 genes changed by 1.5-fold or greater in single treatments of all four LNCaP androgen-deprived subclones; and transcripts for 81 genes changed by 1.5-fold or greater in the three LAPC-4 and LAPC-4 (androgen-deprived) array experiments.

For the experiments described in our study, the raw expression ratio dataset was filtered, using the program Cluster [ 43], for genes whose transcript levels differ from their median value by at least 1.5-fold in androgen-treated cells compared to controls in at least two experiments (with not more than 30% of measurements discarded because of poor data quality for each entry).
One of these, FK506-binding protein 5/FKBP51, a recently described androgen target [ 24], was the most highly induced gene (more than 20-fold) we observed in our experiments.

We were curious to know whether the expression changes observed in LNCaP would also occur in other androgen-responsive human prostate cancer cell lines (MDA PCa 2a, MDA PCa 2b, and LAPC-4), or in LNCaP and LAPC-4 subclones carried in androgen-depleted conditions for extended periods.

We were curious to know whether the expression changes observed in LNCaP would also occur in other androgen-responsive human prostate cancer cell lines (MDA PCa 2a, MDA PCa 2b, and LAPC-4), or in LNCaP and LAPC-4 subclones carried in androgen-depleted conditions for extended periods.

We were curious to know whether the expression changes observed in LNCaP would also occur in other androgen-responsive human prostate cancer cell lines (MDA PCa 2a, MDA PCa 2b, and LAPC-4), or in LNCaP and LAPC-4 subclones carried in androgen-depleted conditions for extended periods.
LNCaP cells were cultured in conditions of androgen deprivation for 48 hours, then exposed to 1 nM of the synthetic androgen R1881 or to ethanol control (0.

In the first, mRNA from each sample of treated or control cells was reverse transcribed to produce Cys-labeled cDNA, and this was compared to a 'common reference' of Cy3-labeled cDNA prepared from mRNA extracted from several cell lines [ 10].

It thresholds the T-statistics to provide a 'significant' gene list and provides an estimate of the false-discovery rate (the percentage of genes identified by chance alone) from randomly permuted data.

It thresholds the T-statistics to provide a 'significant' gene list and provides an estimate of the false-discovery rate (the percentage of genes identified by chance alone) from randomly permuted data.
Indeed, most of the functionally characterized genes induced by androgen in these prostatic cells appear to have important roles in the production of seminal fluid.
